image.altText: Daniel Andrews makes a hand gesture at a press conference. He is outdoors

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Daniel Andrews not expected to appear at inquiry into Commonwealth Games cancellation — Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and his deputy Jacinta Allan are unlikely to appear before a parliamentary inquiry into the state government's decision to pull out of the Commonwealth Games. In an unprecedented move yesterday, the entire Crossbench voted with the Opposition to force a parliamentary inquiry into the debacle. But the upper house inquiry can't compel lower house MPs to appear — including the premier and former Commonwealth Games minister. Leader of the upper house, Jaclyn Symes, says she won't be encouraging them to appear at the public hearings. "This is an upper house inquiry. The Liberal Party knew that this was the rules of engagement when you have an upper house inquiry. "If they wanted to hear from lower house members they could've come to us and considered another forum."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Daniel Andrews not expected to appear at inquiry into Commonwealth Games cancellation

props.alt: A close up of Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews, speaking outside while wearing a suit and glasses

children.content: (AAP: James Ross)
Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and his deputy Jacinta Allan are unlikely to appear before a parliamentary inquiry into the state government's decision to pull out of the Commonwealth Games.
In an unprecedented move yesterday
, the entire Crossbench voted with the Opposition to force a parliamentary inquiry into the debacle.
But the upper house inquiry can't compel lower house MPs to appear
— including the premier and former Commonwealth Games minister.
Leader of the upper house, Jaclyn Symes, says she won't be encouraging them to appear at the public hearings.
"This is an upper house inquiry. The Liberal Party knew that this was the rules of engagement when you have an upper house inquiry.
"If they wanted to hear from lower house members they could've come to us and considered another forum."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand is expected to announce more money and resources for its defence force tomorrow, when Prime Minister Chris Hipkins' Labour government will release the country's first National Security Strategy. As AAP reports, an accompanying strategy report will outline where the government should focus its efforts, tackling emerging issues such as disinformation and economic security, supporting Pacific resilience and strengthening ties in the Indo-Pacific. New Zealand's government has already invested in replacing its Vietnam-era P-3 Orion surveillance planes with P-8 Poseidon aircraft, upgrading its C-130 Hercules cargo planes, and boosting salaries to improve retention. But its defence forces are still stretched thin. The review comes as concerns grow around national security, threats with geostrategic competition heating up and climate change causing more frequent and worse weather events. New Zealand's Defence Minister, Andrew Little, this year said that the country, which spends about 1 per cent of its GDP on defence, would need to make big investments as it faces these challenges.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand is expected to put more money towards defence in its first National Security Strategy

props.alt: A close up of the front windows of an armoured defence truck

children.content: (Supplied: New Zealand Defence Force)

New Zealand is expected to announce more money and resources for its defence force tomorrow, when Prime Minister Chris Hipkins' Labour government will release the country's first National Security Strategy.

As AAP reports, an accompanying strategy report will outline where the government should focus its efforts, tackling emerging issues such as disinformation and economic security, supporting Pacific resilience and strengthening ties in the Indo-Pacific.

New Zealand's government has already invested in replacing its Vietnam-era P-3 Orion surveillance planes with P-8 Poseidon aircraft, upgrading its C-130 Hercules cargo planes, and boosting salaries to improve retention.
But its defence forces are still stretched thin.
The review comes as
concerns grow around national security, threats with geostrategic competition heating up and climate change causing more frequent and worse weather events
New Zealand's Defence Minister, Andrew Little, this year said that the country, which spends about 1 per cent of its GDP on defence, would need to make big investments as it faces these challenges.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: This morning you may have heard about the story of Angela Fitzwater, who lost $26,000 in two bank scams earlier this year. The federal government has promised it will force banks to do better by scam victims with a code of practice, which Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones says could arrive "early next year". "[There is] consultation on it at the moment. It will require legislation. I'm anticipating early next year for the legislation," he says. "That doesn't mean that we can't, on a voluntary basis, do a lot of this work with the code of practice before parliament does its job of legislating. That's what I want to see happening. "There's already work going on in some of the sectors I've mentioned. Not enough. I'm working with colleagues to ensure that we get this moving quicker and with more detail." Jones says he expects the code of practice will outline what protections are required to be put in place by banks, and when banks should pay compensation or reimbursement if those protections aren't followed. You can read about Angela Fitzwater's experience here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Assistant treasurer says anti-scams legislation is likely 'early next year'

featuredLink.title: Angela realised the 'hi mum' scam too late — but feels her bank let her down with what came next

children.content: This morning you may have heard about
the story of Angela Fitzwater
, who lost $26,000 in two bank scams earlier this year.
The federal government has promised it will force banks to do better by scam victims with a code of practice, which Assistant Treasurer Stephen Jones says could arrive "early next year".

props.alt: A middle-aged man in a suit and tie and glasses gives a TV interview in front of a backdrop of Canberra parliament house

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
"[There is] consultation on it at the moment. It will require legislation. I'm anticipating early next year for the legislation," he says.
"That doesn't mean that we can't, on a voluntary basis, do a lot of this work with the code of practice before parliament does its job of legislating. That's what I want to see happening.
"There's already work going on in some of the sectors I've mentioned. Not enough. I'm working with colleagues to ensure that we get this moving quicker and with more detail."

Jones says he expects the code of practice will outline what protections are required to be put in place by banks, and when banks should pay compensation or reimbursement if those protections aren't followed.
You can read about Angela Fitzwater's experience here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The flagship ASX 200 index of the largest 200 listed companies in Australia has opened down at the start of trading. At 10:04AM it was -0.21%, off -21.2 points to 7,333.4 This wasn't unexpected given the weak lead from the US, where the key indices fell after a grim view of future conditions was triggered by a ratings agency downgrading the prospects of the nation's economy.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX 200 opens down after Wall Street's slump

children.content: The flagship ASX 200 index of the largest 200 listed companies in Australia has opened down at the start of trading.
At 10:04AM it was -0.21%, off -21.2 points to 7,333.4

This wasn't unexpected given the weak lead from the US, where the key indices fell after a grim view of future conditions was triggered by a ratings agency downgrading the prospects of the nation's economy.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Morning! Big drops on US indicies have paved the way for what could be some solid loses on the Australian stockmarket. The Dow Jones was down -0.1%, the broader S & P 500 off -1.3% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq a big -2.2% in trade. The US market was shocked by a credit downgrade from one of the key ratings agencies - meaning it thinks the country is a bit riskier for investors than it was yesterday. That can trigger higher interest payments but the biggest blow is probably to confidence in the market. The ASX futures market is at 7,241 points, down 58 points or -0.8%. But we'll see when our market opens at 10AM AEST. Anyway, lots more to come so settle in!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street slump sets stage for ASX falls

children.content: Morning!
Big drops on US indicies have paved the way for what could be some solid loses on the Australian stockmarket.
The Dow Jones was down -0.1%, the broader S
P 500 off -1.3% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq a big -2.2% in trade.
The US market was shocked by a credit downgrade from one of the key ratings agencies - meaning it thinks the country is a bit riskier for investors than it was yesterday.
That can trigger higher interest payments but the biggest blow is probably to confidence in the market.
The ASX futures market is at 7,241 points, down
58 points or -0.8%. But we'll see when our market opens at 10AM AEST.
Anyway, lots more to come so settle in!
